summary: chloroquine treatment prevented liver injury in the early reperfusion phase, but worsened at late phase following hepatic ischemic injury. alanine transaminase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST) were administered to rats 1 h before warm ischemia followed by a daily injection for up to 2 days. hepatocellular necrosis, cytoplasmic vacuolization of hepatocytes and sinusoidal dilation were observed 6 h after reperfusion in vehicle-treated rats. chloroquine-treated rats showed more severe cytoplasmic vacuolization and hepatocellular necrosis 24 h after reperfusion compared with vehicle-treated rats. ine-treated rats showed minimal increases in hepatic TNF-, IL-6, IL-1 and iNOS mRNA levels compared with vehicle-injected animals. Chloroquine treatment decreased liver expression of inflammatory mediators at early phase following I/R injury. chloroquine-treated rats showed lower serum HMGB1 levels. the serum levels of HMGB1 were drastically decreased following reperfusion, to 1.400.41, 1.280.45 ng/ml at 0.5 and 6 h, respectively. phosphorylation of p38 was increased at 0.5 h, decreased at 6 h and then recovered thereafter. treatment with chloroquine did not affect total cellular levels of JNK, p38 and ERK. these data suggest that chloroquine could act upstream of MAP kinase activation. chloroquine treatment increased LC3-II and p62 expression in response to liver I/R injury. results indicated chloroquine inhibited hepatic post-ischemic autophagy. chloroquine treatment increased hepatic apoptosis following I/R
